Cogmind is an easy game to pick up for a roguelike, it has high production quality with tileset graphics (and toggleable ASCII mode), mouse controls (and full keyboard controls too), sound effects and a well designed UI that makes good use of a roguelike style.

Cogmind is an extremely tactical roguelike where every combat encounter has to be started and dealt with caution or avoided completely. A badly thought out fight can turn out sour, leaving you scraping for resources while trying to avoid enemies.
Granted, bottlenecking is mostly the strongest strategy especially in early floors where enemies possess simple weapons incapable of piercing walls and don't have explosives. The reason why combat encounters are so dangerous is because:

You are Cogmind, the little robot that could...
..attach parts to itself, as well as detach them, making you one versatile and dashing metal box. There is no XP, no levels, only parts. And you WILL lose them. And you will replace them. 
Parts can be obtained by scavenging them off other robots, which requires destroying them, or lying around the Complex 0b10 in caches. So combat is not all bad, you get some replacement parts back, but they can be damaged or destroyed in the fight, just like yours.
Once you get to know which kinds of robots use what parts you can start hunting for specific robots based on your needs.
You will have to combine both methods of part scavenging, as neither robots nor caches alone are a completely reliable way of obtaining optimal parts. There are also fabricators that can construct parts from schematics that can be obtained by hacking terminals. It's well possible to make specialized specs, but be always ready to change up to a plan B.
The two obvious ways to play are stealth and combat. Playing as a big tank that carries a bunch of weapons is very easy to start off with, but destroying a lot of enemies raises your alarm level high, which makes the central AI of the complex recognize you as a real threat and send harder and more enemies against you. This means you don't want to fight every patrol you come up against, not only will you be risking your valuable utility parts but making future floors even more difficult. You can pick what to fight by using some sensors to feel upcoming areas, don't load your utility slots with only combatitive parts.
Stealth is harder to learn how to play, you will have to pay a lot of attention to how the enemy AI behaves in different situations and come up with strategies to either go unseen or distract enemies. Speed and scanners are essential for spotting enemy patrols and you can then wait them out in a room, but that is boring, goot thing the game allows for more creative stealth strategies. One of my favorite "stealth" strategies is connecting hallways and rooms by carving tunnels using grenades or rockets to avoid going into hazardous areas. This does cause a lot of noise and has to be timed correctly, don't want a passing patrol come investigate the explosions.

There are many other aspects to Cogmind like the floors that grow different and more difficult in many ways as you make your escape from 0b10, branching side areas that lead to new story paths, terminals that can be hacked for various useful things, resource management in the form of energy/matter/heat systems and much more

38660172.review:
Cogmind is a roguelike game, where you constantly build and rebuild your character. Your capabilities are defined by the items you acquire. There is no experience (no grinding!), you gain 'levels' by climbing to the next floor. This system makes various builds equally viable: combat, speed, stealth, all sorts of hybrids and so on. 

Items are not just stats +X. You will balance energy output, heat generation and support with your combat capabilities, speed and information gathering capabilities. There are over a thousand different items: weapons, power sources, cooling, propulsion, sensors, armors, shields, hackware, build and repair utilities and many, many more. Each item has a cost to use it, with more powerful items typically having bigger costs. There are various synergies and you can get some sick combos! But don't get too attached to the components you currently own, because sooner or later they WILL get destroyed. That's why you constantly need to acquire new parts (they are everywhere!) to rebuild yourself, sometimes completely respecializing to a different build type (You were a heavy tank, machine of destruction, but after a particularly tough fight not much is left of you? Time to become an ultra light jet that zips past enemies before they get a chance to act!).

Levels are procedurally generated, parts you find are randomly chosen, encounters are random (reasonably!). Each playthrough will be different and you will never get bored of it. Even veterans find early levels non-trivial and thus replaying the game is interesting, challenging and fun at all times.

There is an exciting backstory which you discover as you play. With each run you find something new and new things just keep coming! It's actually really fun to hunt for these lore pieces as you play.

This game is 'turn based', but you're not waiting for your opponents to move between your turns. Everything happens immediately. If you can click fast enough, you could do a 100 turns per second. Only when you need more time to make a decision (or contemplate your inevitable doom) the game will slow down for you. Think of this 'turn based' system more like an active pause - you get as much time as you want when you want it, but otherwise game moves forward smoothly. Even better - you can fast-forward less exciting parts like exploration (when nothing of interest is found) or waiting for that patrol to pass by.

I love this game: it's unique, it's challenging, I get to manage the risks I take, story is awesome and game is hugely replayable!

This game however is not for everyone and here I'd like to point out some common reasons not to buy this game (if applicable to you; you are the final judge):
[list]
	[*]Randomness - there's a lot of randomness: floor layouts, encounters, parts you find. It's not a slot-machine-kind random. It's more like some card games randomness (i.e. Hearthstone). You get to make your choices and manage your risks at all times. You are guaranteed to get something and if you're versatile enough, you will get something useful. But hoping to get a very specific item will not get you this specific item most of the time. 
	[*]Permadeath - you will die a lot and then you will need to start from a scratch. Game is designed around this, so that repeating early levels is not boring, but still challenging even after dozens of times. Having fun in such games is a matter of mindset. Remember: you are not supposed to win this game. Have fun trying out new builds and optimizing old ones. Think how can you improve, what tactics and strategies can you deploy. Learn from your loss. Try beating your previous score. I'll repeat: you are not supposed to win. Thinking otherwise will bring disappointment to you.
	[*]Graphics - you can see it in the screenshots and it's a common thing to drive players away from games like this one. Decide whether you're fine with it.
	[*]Font size - BIG WARNING HERE: UI is designed to have a certain minimum number of rows and many smaller screens (including some laptops) cannot fit this many rows of readably large font. Check this [url=http://www.gridsagegames.com/cogmind/ui_preview.html]link (provided in the game description as well)[/url] to see how this game will look on your screen.
	[*]Keybindings - There are multiple predefined control schemes, including pure mouse, pure keyboard, Vi keys. Custom keybindings [strike]are not a thing[/strike] require manually changing files and some players are complaining about it.
[/list]

I've been a casual fan of traditional roguelikes for a long time, and it's been fun to see the genre get picked up and taken in new directions, though it's often been through a mashup of genres—e.g.The Binding of Isaac—which results in fun and interesting games which owe a debt of inspiration to rogulikes but ultimately are something quite different. Cogmind, however, is a traditional roguelike that evolves the genre.

It has a terrific UI. As advertised the game takes full advantage of mouse or keyboard modes of input. Both modes are comfortable and it is great to see a roguelike taking advantage of drag-and-drop and right click context menus. My favorite method of input is still the keyboard. I never need to reach for the mouse and I am not missing anything. All of the contextual information and ease of use provided by the mouse has equivalents within the keyboard controls. It is really nicely done.

At its heart, Coglike is a game of exchangeable parts. You build yourself up out of the pieces of your slain enemies. (Or, sometimes the quasi-innocent bystanders that are busy doing their own jobs.) The variety of items feels expansive, and there are numerous item interactions—not the charming but frustratingly opaque interactions of Nethack, but of a more narrowly logical variety; i.e. some items make other items work better. Will there be surprises? Or are the surprises reserved for the story line?

We are not told what the point of the game is. There is no Amulet of Yendor driving the action of Cogmind. We just know we need to get out, to do something, to go somewhere. Discovering what Cogmind is about is one of the mysteries of Cogmind. Who is Cogmind? What is the context and history of this world? Is it Earth? When is it? I frankly do not know whether Cogmind is a freedom fighter or an evil robot. Delicious little bits of data are dropped from time to time, like breadcrumbs leading... somewhere.

There are a couple areas where I could dream of having a little more quality of life customizability, of the kind which I can provide myself in other roguelikes that run within a terminal emulator: fonts and colors.

The Cogmind screen is dense with information. There is a map, and surrounding it are panels containing various textual elements. I prefer ASCII graphics in roguelikes because they remain crisp and clear, and are easily identifiable at much smaller sizes than graphic sprites. Tiles may be pretty, but they are less distinct and require more detail to deliver the equivalent information. At 1920x1080 on a 24" screen I find myself wishing I could make the map font smaller and the text font slightly larger. And while I might kind of wish that I could substitute my own favorite font variants, the game does include a large number of fonts of various sizes and visual characteristics which can be used for the panels of text. The map font currently defaults to a square sci-fi themed font. That it is square is a good thing, as it makes the map tidily grid-like, but I find the letter shapes trade a little bit of clarity for aesthetics. 

[Update—See my comments to Kyzrati re: the map font. TL;DR: Give the default map font some time. The glyphs may not have the kind of clarity desirable for reading text, but as isolated entities on a map they are really quite good and they support the aesthetics of the game.]

The other element I would prefer some control over is the color palette. When playing roguelikes in a traditional terminal emulator I typically create a profile with a color palette that has just the right amount of contrast for my monitor and for my eyes. This, again, is due to day-long work sessions staring at a screen that wants to burn my eyes out. With Cogmind I find some of the colors, particularly the lighter green, becomes a little bright and tiring after a while. And though it would probably be aesthetic anathema, I might really prefer not to have to stare at green on black. Aesthetically it is the right choice. It has the right sensibility for the game. But strictly in terms of ease of viewing, a sea of green on black can be a bit much after a long day. 

These really are minor complaints however, in a UI that is far superior to any traditional roguelike I’ve ever played. A lot of effort has been invested in making the game as interactive and user friendly as it is, and I do not want to appear unappreciative of this. And I suspect these are things that may be addressed with a future modding API. The developer is incredibly responsive and present in the community. 

Cogmind is a lot of fun and I look forward to spending plenty of time with it. Maybe one day I'll escape, or transcend, or destroy the whole damned place. Who knows?

Summary
Cogmind is a traditional turn based rogue like where you manage your robots inventory and components. You can equip your bot to be a fast flying hacker, or a tank treading missile launcher and many more!

This game does not feel like an Early Access or Beta. It is fully playable, fun, with no bugs (as far as I have seen).

Pros

- Lots of surprises if you can live long enough to find them
- Story and lore to keep you coming back to learn more
- Very challenging

Cons
- Small font might make it inaccessible to some people.

- Very challenging (this could be a pro or con depending on your tastes)

Long review.
I first heard about this game on Steam and quickly starting looking in to Let's Plays and reading about it.
I have had a hard time finding a traditional Roguelike that I enjoyed. Most had bad UI or bad controls or just did not provide enough of something new each time to interest me. I very much enjoy many modern rogueLITES (ftl, dungeon of the endless, steredenn, enter the gungeon etc..) So the ideas of traditional roguelikes are very appealing to me but most have failed to provide the experience I was hoping for.

Cogmind has since changed that. It provides a great focus on usability and player feedback. Animations and sounds all provide the player with the theme and feedback that makes it "feel" polished. Each time I play I find a bit of lore or an npc or surprise event that I have never experienced before. This really encourages that "one more turn/floor" feeling.

Cogmind requires a lot of inventory management and you will be constently making decisions on what to keep and how to "build" your robot. There are many "systems" that interact with each other and learning how everything works is a big part of Cogmind (and roguelikes in general).

Trying new and weird things is encouraged by this game. After each death (and there will be many) I always think of what new "thing" I could try.  New robot build, new tactic, new path through the world, how do I get back to that awesome event that I just found...

The developer has been working for several years and has released a fully playable game. Why it's even early access I don't know. Just know there is more "stuff" to come.

I feel comfortable recommending this game in Early Access at Full Price! It is well worth it. You can also check out the Gridsage game website to provide the dev with more support if you are able.

Cogmind is one of the most innovative roguelikes to come out in recent years.  Despite nominally being in Early Access, the amount of content and level of polish is high.  You play a lone robot trying to escape from hostile territory one floor at a time.  The gameplay blends traditional roguelike elements (turn-based combat on a grid, procedural generation, permadeath) with a unique equipment and build system.  

Your capabilities are basically entirely determined by the items you have equipped.  You need to balance concerns such as mobility, vulnerability of systems to damage, and heat accumulation.  Almost every item is obtained by random stockpiles or scavenged from fallen enemies, and your equipped parts inevitably get damaged and destroyed in combat.  This means that you often have to improvise your loadout based on what is on hand.  As you ascend you choose which types of equipment slots (power, propulsion, utility, or weapons) to add.

Like a number of games in the genre, Cogmind is quite difficult.  There are two easier difficulty settings if you are just starting out or wanting a more casual experience, but the standard game mode is quite unforgiving.  The complex is essentially a simulated ecosystem, filled with both noncombatant and security robots.  The more disruptive you are, the more the general alert level rises, leading to more and more dangerous enemies hunting you down.  Thus, even combat-focused builds are incentivized to avoid unnecessary encounters.  Staying on any given level for longer than absolutely necessary (for example, if you're looking to enter or avoid a particular branch) is a deliberate risk. 

The game is a traditional roguelike in its presentation, which is to say that the graphics options are 'ASCII characters only' and '2d tiles'.  Note that the game is fixed around displaying a certain grid size, so the game can look compressed on small displays.  My experience with a small screen is that the ASCII mode is quite readable, but if this is a potential concern you should examine full-resolution screenshots to evaluate this issue for yourself.  While the graphics aren't fancy, the green terminal aesthetic is immersive, especially combined with the excellent sound design.

The controls have two modes.  The mouse mode is intuitive and good for anyone starting out with this game or roguelikes in general, and the traditional roguelike keyboard mode is well-optimized for veterans, albeit more complex.  Customizing keybinds is an option, although it's a little arcane.

Due to its unique mechanics, I recommend Cogmind wholeheartedly for anyone interested in roguelikes.  Anyone interested in a system for customizing their own robot a la Battletech should take a look as well.  The game has a large amount of content (much of it in optional branches outside of the main path of levels) and also has superb replayability due to both procedural generation and strategic depth.

Note: My 'Hours Played' statistic on Steam does not account for the fact that I play the game with the Steam client inactive.  I run the game on a Mac using a Wineskin (which works well), and have over 30 hours of playtime (which is admittedly only enough to scratch the surface of the game).

[u][b]Some Context[/b][/u]

Almost three years ago I discovered the 7DRL version of Cogmind while skimming through the Devlog posts on IndieDB.  What caught my attention was a post from Kyzrati detailing the development of a full version of his Sci-Fi Roguelike prototype, the very clear expectations he had set for himself, and the passion he had for the project.  Jump to today and his passion has not abated.  The added features through community discussion are numerous, yet he has managed to remain true to his vision for the game.  I played regularly during the Alpha (up to Alpha 4) and played occasionally up to the Steam release to see how things were progressing.  Seeing the game progress hugely over the years has been impressive and the current result is, in my opinion, the best Roguelike available on Steam.

[u][b]The Game[/b][/u]

Cogmind is an ambitious game and succeeds in updating the Roguelike genre.  While the gameplay is turn-based it is not your typical Roguelike if you are used to playing Caves of Qud or Tales of Maj’Eyal.  There is no levelling in the traditional sense as there are no skill trees or initial customisation for your character.  Instead, levelling is strongly tied to the equipment you find/salvage/steal and will drastically change how you play the game.  As you ascend you increase the number of pieces of equipment you can equip and your base health.  Equipment can be damaged and destroyed so you will need to adapt and upgrade as you ascend through the levels.  Mechanically similar Roguelikes would include Brogue or The Ground Gives Way.  I personally prefer this system because as soon as you open the game you are in the world, making progress, and making tangible decisions.

This is a cliché, but expect to die… [i]A lot[/i].  Regularly dying early might give you the impression that there is not much to this game.  This is not the case.  The initial levels only give you access to a limited selection of what is on offer.  There are branching paths, wild variation in a vast range weapons and utilities, a large selection of hostile/neutral/allied robots, and an extensive, well-written lore.  After only a few hours of play you will find that you can progress through the early levels in about 10-15 minutes after which the game really opens up.  I have never successfully completed a run ([i]I have come close[/i]), but there are players that regularly beat the game with a variety of builds and the developer has created the game with the intention that every run has the potential to win.  Check out [u][url=https://www.youtube.com/user/kwrkrlz]zxc’s[/url][/u] YouTube channel if you want to see how it’s done.

You have a choice between using the traditional ASCII tiles or a graphical tile-set and by hitting F3 you can toggle between the two depending on preference.  No matter what you choose the visuals are beautiful and destructive with accompanying sound effects that really help to immerse you in the game’s world.  I use the ASCII tiles simply because I find it easier to parse the information on-screen due to the time spent with the 7DRL version.  The ASCII tile-set has a wide variation of fonts so you should be able to find one you prefer.  At this stage there is only one, official graphical tile-set, but player-made tile-sets are possible.

The lone developer has and continues to release regular improvements and additions to the game.  What is there is a complete and enjoyable gaming experience.  If you like following detailed, well-written progress updates I highly recommend checking out the [url=http://www.gridsagegames.com/blog/][u]Devlog[/u][/url], where you will see the great lengths required to create a game as polished as this.

I've been closely following the development of Cogmind for almost four years (almost since the start, really). Don' be scared by the fact that it is early access: it already was an awesome game to play from the first alpha, and is has only gotten better since! And it is more polished and bug-free than many big-budget games are on their official release.

Cogmind can probably best be described as a turn-based scifi stealth-action modernised traditional roguelike. And no, "modernised traditional" is not an oxymoron in this context.

"Roguelike as in Spelunky?" Well... no... that's what the "traditional" signifies. Explaining what a traditional roguelike would take too long - search "Nethack" and do a wikipedia dive. The important bit is that the focus in these games is weaving intricate, interconnected game systems together. Gameplay consists of meaningful choices, where the world built out of these systems responds to us poking and prodding it, to create a rich experience in the process. Graphics often take a backseat to that, and you need to use your imagination to immerse yourself. The richness of the game system usually makes that quite easy!

The downside of all the complexity usually is that the interface also suffers, with I-don't-know how many special commands for input (imagine a fantasy game, like NetHack. In them, you can usually use, zap, drop, throw, break, give, and even (try to) eat a wand. [i]Each of those actions has a separate key[/i], and that's just the tip of the iceberg). But not with Cogmind! The interface of this game is streamlined and user-friendly - I am an interface designer by profession and training, and I [i][b]LOVE[/b][/i] this game's interface so incredibly much: it can be completely mouse-controlled, completely keyboard-controlled, or both, and everything about it is incredibly polished.

Same with the gameplay: from the player's perspective, this game is as complex as you want it to be. Instead of requiring you to read a huge manual before you can even get started, you can just start to move around, pick up some gear and equip it, and start shooting your way out, without knowing anything about the intricate systems that make the game tick.

However, to enjoy it to the most, you should be the type to like diving into the various game systems. But her too, Cogmind makes this as easy and frictionless as possible. The whole thing is set up to give elegant, in-game access to learning how the systems work. Hovering over anything gives you information pop-ups, right-clicking gives bigger pop-ups with EVEN MORE detailed information. Want to compare two items? Right click on one, then another, and it will also show the difference in stats for easier comparison! So pick apart the stats decide when to use wheels and when to use robo-legs. Or play it like a mindless coffee-break game, pick up the first weapons you see and shoot every hostile bot that comes your way, and see how far you get until you're inevitably overwhelmed, pew pew!

And that's just the interface! Cogmind pushes traditional roguelikes into new ground on so many different fronts: the UI, the ASCII art animations, the sound design, the game mechanics themselves. I could go on for hours praising this game!

This is all the brain-child of one man: Josh Ge, a.k.a. Kyzrati. He is very reliable and open to user-feedback. When I replied to one of his blog-entries that I am color-blind and had some trouble with the colour scheme at times, he immediately started working on ways to avoid that: adding other non-color ways of communicating status, a mod-friendly system for the color palette, and so on. How amazing is that?

Carl Sagan once said "If you wish to make an apple pie from scratch, you must first invent the universe." I think he was making a philosophical point, but Josh must have mistaken it for a dare. Cogmind is the product of a person who loves a genre of games so much that he broke it down, obsessively deconstructing [i]absolutely everything[/i] about it: evaluating, re-evaluating and re-re-evaluating every design decision, every convention, basically every aspect you can think of, again and again, to get to the essence of what a roguelike [i]is[/i]. And in the process, from the ground up, he meticulously crafted this game.

If you have read his (highly recommended) devlog, I'm sure you agree with me that he has worked on this with an almost disturbing level of devotion for four years. This is a Herculean labour of love. And for what purpose? To drag traditional roguelikes kicking and screaming into modernity, so that everyone else will see what it is that he loves so much about them. In my opinion, that makes it a work of art. And luckily for of us, a damn good game.

This is something much more than it seems; it is a take on a classic, proven formula for roguelike (not lite) exploration with absolutely new mechanics that make it a brand new experience. I have at least 6,000 hours in roguelikes, half of which is Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup.

Instead of leveling, you select new slots; power sources (important for energy weapons and shields), propulsion (important for movement and evasion, also total weight), utility (the one slot you can never have too many of), and weaponry. You start with 2 of each, and you get more as you go deeper. Killing enemies gives a chance for new parts, but also a high chance of a net loss. You have matter, which is used for kinetic weapon firing, and energy, used for energy weapon firing. Both also interplay with utilities, and utilities can convert one to the other.

Adding parts has just enough of a cost to not be done excessively but allowing for regular upgrades. And parts themselves have two stats; the amount of HP they have, and coverage. The only way to die is to get hit in your core, and the only way to defend it is to have parts. Weapons, propulsion, and certain utilities (especially armor) contribute most to this. However, parts regularly take damage from combat and will eventually break.

A main restriction is inventory space, which can only be expanded from an absolutely insufficient 4 with utility upgrades. I try to get by with +10, but +20 would help a lot...

'Builds', as they are, is twofold: Selecting upgrade slots and then finding the appropriate items. However, things will change. I've played alot of roguelikes of various sorts, whether they be turn-based, or real-time (no, I dont care about the term "rogueLITE").  The turn-based ones though, are often things I dont get along with.  Such as Nethack for example, which I've never liked (blasphemy!) with it's irritating "your character is dumber than a stump, so every item ever is unidentified, and may explode, HAHA SCREW YOU" sort of mechanics.  Not to mention that they're usually filled with really strange, obscure, and nearly hidden mechanics that are almost impossible to find and understand on your own.  Everything is always hidden, nothing is explained, and just... you get the idea.  Oh, and the UI is typically horrible.  HORRIBLE.  I always wanted a good turn-based roguelike that went AWAY from these concepts instead of just trying to be the 396734th Nethack clone.

Enter Cogmind:  Exactly the game I've been wanting for who knows how long.  A game which keeps the very high complexity and depth of the "core" roguelikes, yet removes all of the problems I've always hated, and replaces them with very well thought-out mechanics of it's own that really make it stand out, and that ooze with quality.

Cogmind's concept is that you're this... floaty robot thing.  You start out as just a core, and you'll then assemble yourself from parts scattered nearby. Legs, treads, guns, reactors, whatever.  These items are all-important, as they define the entirity of your build as well as your abilities.  No EXP or anything here.  But while it's your core's HP that keeps you alive, much of the incoming damage will hit the parts you have equipped.  Before long, some of them will shatter, and you'll have to get new ones.  Good thing this works the other way around as well.  Wreck your robotic foes, and take THEIR parts for yourself.  Unlike you, enemy bots have extremely low amounts of core HP, so destroying them doesnt mean that most of their parts will shatter first.  Still, sometimes you might get a part that's mostly undamaged, and other times you may be stuck with a pile of gizmos that are missing some pieces.  But they'll just have to do.  Rolling with the punches is a huge part of the gameplay, and you'll need to adapt to the situation as well as what items are accessible to you.

Fortunately, there's alot more to it than that.  This is not a game where the RNG alone will kill you.  Finding parts isnt exactly an uncommon occurance. They are everywhere, and there's about a bazillion different types.  Weapons, power sources, utilities... all sorts of awesome stuff.  And they dont just come from shattered bots.  The facility that you're crawling through is filled with all sorts of parts lying around for you to find.  You are given many, many options, very frequently, allowing you to make choices in just how you want to build yourself up.  What's more, these parts are actually INTERESTING.  Deathrays and missile launchers and other crazy weapons are fun and all, but there's more to it than just those.  Utilities in particular can do all sorts of different things.  You might find a targeting processor, giving you more accuracy.  Or you might find a terrain scanner, capable of finding hidden maintenance doors, allowing new avenues of escape.  Or perhaps units to help you hack things, signal jammers, and many others, each more creative than the last.  All of these constantly changing parts make sure that your character and setup never grow stale over the course of the run.

Speaking of hacking, that's another major aspect.  You'll find all sorts of terminals as you explore.  Terminals have boatloads of different functions, but you're not a normal user... you're a rogue bot, and needless to say, you dont exactly have security clearance.  If you want to use these many, many functions... and you do... you'll have to risk hacking these things.  Hacks may fail, they may be detected, they may start a trace routine, leading investigation squads to your location.  But the info and services you can get from hacking is invaluable.  You may get schematics for crafting, or perhaps the chance to see the status and location of security patrols, or many other things.  You have TONS of options here, and the hacking mechanic adds alot to the game overall.  

Even with all of those options though, this is one DIFFICULT game.  It's not going to murder you outright.  This isnt one of those roguelikes where some monster can come around the corner and tear you in half with one hit.  It's specifically designed so that DOESNT happen.  If you lose, it's in a non-frustrating way, and there's always a chance to examine where you went wrong, rather than going "What the heck, how was I supposed to deal with that?".  And that's good, because you WILL lose.  Alot.  Your enemies are extremely numerous, and the more trouble you cause, the more concerned and aggressive the central AI will become, sending out larger and more powerful squads after you.  In addition you have to deal with all sorts of traps, each more insidious than the last.  But as with everything else, you have things you can do to counter all of this.  But it's up to you to figure out how to use the tools available.

Oh, and I also want to mention the UI:  It is amazing.  Usually... okay, pretty much always... roguelikes get this horribly wrong, with confusing, broken interfaces that dont make much sense and are hard to even use.  But not this one.  This game goes out of it's way to make everything accessible, and to give you information in a way that's nice and easy to understand.  It's the best interface I've ever seen in one of these.  Not to mention that the game is just gorgeous.  Not just the default tileset, but... everything.  The animated explosions and energy blasts, or even the interface itself, it all fits the game and really emphasizes everything that is going on.  It also makes it easier to see just what's happening.  If a bullet you fire hits it's target, you will SEE it hit it's target, and you'll also see if you did core damage.  You dont have to stare at the combat log the whole time just to see what is going on.  I normally never bring up things like graphics when I review a game, but this one deserves a special mention... it's just that good.

Overall, the game is fantastic.  I honestly cant really think of anything I dislike about it.  It's accessible yet incredibly complicated and deep.  It has an insane amount of content.  There's tons of things to do.  The combat system is fantastic.  The game world is detailed, with tons to see and lore behind all of it.  The challenge is extremely high, but you're given so many options to deal with it... the possibilities are endless, and you're not restricted to any specific playstyle.  Whether you prefer stealth, or want to crash through situations and blow up entire rooms (did I mention EVERYTHING is destructible?), you have that choice, and it's viable.

There's so very, very much more I could talk about here, all of it positive.  But Steam only allows me so much room.  An incredible game that will pull you in and not let go.  You'll die alot, but you'll love every moment of it, and you'll always learn more.  One of the most satisfying roguelikes I've seen, and very highly recommended.

A love letter to the roguelike genre, Cogmind fundamentally examines each of the mechanics behind that type of game and turns them into games of their own.  

What's a @ do?  Well, they move.  So what if we make your character a robot that you can swap in varous types of mobility, from legs to wheels to hovercraft.  A @ attacks, so how about your character can attach weapons to itself and fires them all per turn.  A @ restores energy per turn to do things, lets look at that somewhat literally, energy in the form of power generators and batteries.  A @ does all sorts of interesting utility things,  lets stick those in utility slots.  Your inventory becomes your character, and the entirety of your character becomes this sort of evolving classless microcosm with lovely, lovely stat numbers.

What about the map?  Well, the map should be generated with a high degree of variety and excellent procedural generation mechanics.  Done.  But what if we want to make the map a living thing?  What if it's inhabited by robots which actually move around the level, expanding the map, rebuilding lost bits, picking up and moving scrap?  Lets give everyone and everything on the map a reason to be there.  Now *this* is a roguelike map with some significance!

How about the lore?  Given that all the robots on the map have a reason to be there, you emerge as a strange robot looking to understand a strange world. A certain satisfactory dynamic narrative emerges, not only a greater understanding of this robot-run world, but your character's place in it.

It all ties together expertly, with a craftman's attention to nailing the fundamentals and implementation.  All this, well worth your $20, rock solid and playable, and he calls it an Early Access game.

Cogmind is an amazing game. I've been playing it since Alpha 1, way back in mid-2015. Hundreds of hours. Now it's finally hit Steam Early Access, but it's fair to call it one of the most complete games to ever go through EA.

You are the Cogmind, a strange kind of robot. In your bid to reach the surface of a mysterious underground complex, you attach parts to yourself, building yourself into a stealthy flight bot fitted out with sensors, or you know, a walking death machine. It's up to you and what you find. You'll encounter many neutral robots going about their business, as well as quite a few hostile ones who seem to want nothing more than to tear your robot core apart. The combat is tactically rich, and there are definitely more reviews which go into more detail there, but I want to focus on stealth, which is really my jam in games. The stealth experience in Cogmind is raw, and gets to the heart of what I love about stealth in games: gathering information you can use to avoid enemies. If you find and attach a sensor array, you can observe the movement of nearby enemy patrols and take evasive action. Perhaps you attach a terrain scanner and spot that a nearby wall is thin enough to dig through to the other side, bypassing a corridor crawling with enemies. You can use transmission jammers to silence distress calls, optics to increase your LOS range, ECM suites to lose your pursuers quickly, cloaks to reduce the range at which enemies spot you, structural scanners to detect hidden passages... I've had some intense moments where I've been cornered, hiding behind a machine, hoping that the hunters searching for me aren't too thorough with my room. It's such a unique experience for a roguelike, and really brings stealth to a new level. I haven't even mentioned the diverse hostile robot types, terminal hacks, or some of the absolutely crazy unique items you can sometimes find, which may completely alter your strategy. Also, you can reach movement speeds so fast that sentries won't even know you've flown right past them.

Before we dig further into the game, I want to make some brief points on the difficulty and learning curve. This game is a traditional roguelike (despite the modern ideas and polish), and it has all the difficulty you'd expect of one. You're going to get brutally butchered in this game, and rightfully so. It's going to take a lot to get good at Cogmind, but the pleasure from mastering difficult games is one of the main reasons we play them (and especially roguelikes). The game starts off simply, and holds back the coolest areas, lore, and items for later. This is to avoid overwhelming the player at the start, and makes a lot of sense within the context of the game. But you'll probably still get wrecked early on if you don't apply good tactics and positioning. As the game goes on, it gets harder, and the items become more diverse and build-enabling. Cogmind has a much wider set of strategic variables to consider than other roguelikes I've played, and pure tactical ingenuity won't be enough to save you if you make grave strategic misplays down the road. If it's too hot to handle, or if you just want a more chilled game, Cogmind has two easier difficulty modes in the options. There is also a mix of challenge modes in case you really want to be stretched to breaking point. ;)

Story isn't a major component in most roguelikes, and it's been a while since I've played a game with a story I've connected with, regardless of genre. Somehow, against all the expectations I had, Cogmind tells a stellar story, one that has kept me absorbed and thinking about the implications away from my computer just like the best sci-fi films do. You learn bits and pieces about the world and its inhabitants through terminal records scattered throughout the game, but the real gems of lore and story come from exploring the hard-to-reach places in the game. The story is so tightly and expertly woven into the gameplay that you can't help but get drawn into it as you play. Your choices have a large impact on the story and its resolution, and the story has a large impact on your choices. It's kind of hard to explain, so I'll leave you to discover it yourself. On a related note: Cogmind is filled with secrets, and some of them have a [i]huge[/i] impact on gameplay and also how the pieces of the world and story fit together in your mind, so I [i]highly[/i] recommend you play this game as unspoiled as you can. You have to do some proper detective work to figure everything out, and it's all the more rewarding when you do.

Now let me tell you about the production values, which are immense, starting with sound. I normally keep sound disabled when playing roguelikes. Not so, with Cogmind. Playing this game without sound is unimaginable. There are sounds for [i]everything[/i], and they're so authentic. They really ramp up the atmosphere and draw you into the world. The satisfying sounds of dying robots and the deep rumble of a chain of nuclear reactors exploding just take the cake for sound design in a game. It's the little things, too, like the subtle audio cues when interacting with the interface, and the forbidding ambience of the caves.

Next: the visuals. You have two ways to view the world: the tile set, and ASCII. I myself use the ASCII, which is beautiful and clear. Both options are highly expressive. The animations are grand as well. Most of the combat in the game is ranged, but between the sounds and animations, you can tell pretty much all of the weaponry apart. The explosions are glorious. Even in their aftermath, the walls have collapsed, rubble is strewn everywhere, and the floor is burnt to a black crisp. Every single item has special ASCII art associated with it, and it's phenomenal. There's even a gallery to view all the items you've ever equipped in all their ASCII art splendour, complete with item stats. Gotta equip 'em all! (there's a lore-dex for the lore you've found too)

Now, for the user interface. UI in this genre is too frequently a barrier to players rather than a welcoming conduit between you and the awesome gameplay you know is there somewhere. Fortunately, Cogmind knocks this one out of the park, I mean, seriously, AAA game studios could learn a lot right here. In a game largely about items and information, the UI is vital to get right. Mouse users and keyboard users alike are first-class citizens here. I play exclusively with the keyboard, and all the controls are efficient and polished. The HUD is aesthetically pleasing too, fitting right in with the sci-fi setting of the game. All of this must've been a nightmare of work for the developer, but it's paid off dearly for the players. Lucky us!

This game is a work of art. It's remarkable that one person made all of this (apart from the tile set). You've got to check this out.

[b]RECOMMENDED![/b]

35788170.review:
An amazing game from an amazing genre by an amazing developer, Cogmind really has it all. I started playing Cogmind back in Alpha 12, and over the course of about a year the game has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time. There are just so many things Cogmind does right that it's hard to name them all in one place, but I'll do my best to touch on some of the best aspects of the game:

UI:
Cogmind has the best UI of any roguelike in existence. It's entirely mouse friendly (though can be played with only a keyboard as well), displays TONS of data transparently (so much that many people are overwhelmed at the sheer amount, though this can be turned off), and has popups for everything (if you have any questions about a UI element, simply hover your mouse over it and a popup will tell you all about it). The UI is so fantastic and innovative that it's hard to play other roguelikes after playing Cogmind. 

Art Style / Animation:
10/10. Whether you play in ASCII or Tiles you will not be disappointed with the look of the game. Cogmind makes excellent use of colors to help the player clearly identify friend from foe, and even distinguish difficult enemies from easy ones. The animations are also out of this world... pick up any explosive launcher and fire it to see a spectacular explosion of vibrant color, making large scale battles really amazing to see. Some animations even affect the UI, which I think looks absolutely awesome.

Sound Effects:
10/10. No other roguelike comes close to matching the quality of sound in Cogmind. Every weapon has a unique sound, most explosions have unique sounds, there are unique ambient sounds throught the levels... even the stationary machines make sounds! The sound effects really bring the game world alive, and add a level of immersion that I didn't realize I was missing with traditional roguelikes.

Story:
10/10. I really don't want to say much here (as cogmind is very spoilery and I'd hate to ruin that for anyone), but *wow* is the story good. There are secrets *everywhere*, so much lore to find, and all kinds of things that make you rethink what you think you know about the game. There's even a *huge* twist that most people will never know about... Only the truly dedicated will figure out who's pulling all the strings ;) I've already said too much, so please do yourself a favor and discover this stuff yourself.

Gameplay:
The last category, but also the most important category, is gameplay... and Cogmind excels here as well. There are so many different ways to play through Cogmind, mostly differentiated (but not entirely) by the different propulsion available to you throughout the game. Flight often means stealth (real stealth, btw, no fake mechanics... you stealth by actively avoiding enemies and staying out of their sight), whereas legs or treads often mean combat (guns and explosions, hurray!) Due to Cogmind's extensive use of item destruction, you are not stuck to any type of build throughout the game... rather, you'll find that your builds will evolve as you find things / lose parts. Item attrition is a major component of whether a run will be succesful or not, so it very important to plan carefully. "Do I enter a midgame branch and risk my current parts for the possibility of reward, or do I quickly run through main levels and risk becoming underpowered?" These are the types of questions you will ask yourself as you play. Without giving too much away, I can assure you that the game is exactly as challenging as you want it to be; play it safe and a normal Access win shouldn't be too difficult, but take on some branches / extended and the difficulty will ramp up fast. 

I also want to mention that one of my favorite aspects of Cogmind is the ability to "comeback". Since you're characters power is largely determined by the items equipped, should you lose all those items it may seem like all hope is lost... but it's not! Cogmind can very easily run from most situations and rebuild from parts found around the complex, leading to some really spectacular comebacks. Just earlier on stream today I lost all of my flight propulsion to EM traps, and managed to rebuild just a bit later w/ some hover units I found, saving the day! This mechanic really makes for some dramatic and tense moments, which I find exhilarating. 

Overall:
11/10. Cogmind is a Masterpiece. If all of that isn't enough to convince you to buy the game, then the final thing I will say is this... Kyzrati, the Developer, is an amazing person who has done wondeful things for the Roguelike community. Check out his blog (http://www.gridsagegames.com/blog/) or the subreddit's he moderates (roguelikes.reddit.com and roguelikedev.reddit.com) to see just how much of an impact he makes. The gaming industry needs more dev's like him, and that alone is worth supporting this amazing game in my book.

BUY THIS GAME. You will not regret it.

"Dynamic character development without XP/grinding"
When the store page says you can be a slow well-armed tank, or a fast-moving flier, or a stealthy assassin/hacker, or whatever else; you will probably be at least two or three of those options per playthrough if you live long enough. Purchased during Alpha, before Steam release. I've got many hours in this game unlisted as a result.

Cogmind is one of those beautiful gems you didn't think you'd ever find. Appearing at first to be a regular ascii roguelike, where you have to learn VIM or use unintuitive numpad controls, memorizing a bunch of keyboard shortcuts, it soon becomes apparent that it's much more than that. I'm new to the turn-based roguelike genre, but if you're looking to get into them, or are bored of playing every "shooter roguelike" that releases, THIS IS THE PLACE TO START.

Cogmind is beautifully complex, but presented simply. It's easy for a newcomer to the genre to understand (like myself), but from my understanding, it's complex and difficult enough for even veterans to enjoy. You can use mouse controls, keybaord controls, or a combination of the two to control the game, so it is instantly playable by anyone. There is barely any tutorial, but akin to games of old, encourages you to explore the interface and world, discovering the different ways you can interact with your equipment, the environment, and other robots, as well as with different playstyles.

To someone new to the turn based roguelike genre, it feels much more like an open world RPG that has permadeath than any other roguelike I've dabbled with. If you enjoy games like Skyrim or Fallout due to their many gameplay styles, I would wager you'll enjoy this game.

Throughout the time I've owned the game in Alpha, I've seen the game updated a dizzying number of times, with many features added to the game. Don't let the Early Access tag dissuade you, this game is like Rimworld or Factorio, where "Early Access" simply means "Yeah, we're gonna keep updating this game, like, a lot, but if Early Access didn't exist, it'd be pretty much finished."

TLDR; If you're new or old to the roguelike genre, I can't recommend this game enough. $20 is a steal.

I initially bought this game back in Alpha 13 due to some favorable comparisons to Brogue. Brogue appealed to me as a game with great tactical depth and meaningful decision-making, where every run was vastly different and you had to actually focus to make it out alive, couldn't just set up the same-ish thing in every seed once you'd learned the game a bit.

I have now played Cogmind for some hundreds of hours. While the game is less demanding than Brogue (from the perspective of simply winning, which is still quite challenging), with less seed variance (an approach with pros and cons), the game has effectively managed to appeal to me in a similar manner, in consistently providing decisions with satisfying amounts of complexity that can lead to some very interesting results. There is little in gaming that has been more fun to me than designing various killer-robots consisting of over 20 salvaged/found/fabricated parts in the lategame, with a similar amount of items in inventory, constantly modifying the specific layout based on finding better parts or simply replacements/alternatives to damaged ones, getting some actual pusback from the Complex such that even the best bots still have to think about their actions.

I would recommend the game to anyone with an appreciation for challenging and complex game mechanics, and Cogmind gets a lot of bonus points for presenting that complexity in a way that is viscerally satisfying, this is the one clear advantage Cogmind has over Brogue and similar games: it's rare to get such strategic depth [i]and[/i] astonishing sound effects, beautiful ASCII art for over 800 items, lore entries that add a lot of flavor to exploring the world, and an actual interesting story to discover, even if it is difficult to fully discover, being sort of in the background and featuring challenges beyond simply making it out of the Complex alive.

This is a superbly executed game in the traditional roguelike style. Permadeath. Procedurally generated content. Easy to learn, difficult to master but rewarding every step of the way. I've gotten in early here with a review on Steam but I strongly suspect you're going to see a huge mountain of Positive reviews as people start catching on to just how good this is. Been playing this one for about 6 months in Beta and I have to say... IT'S ABSOLUTELY AWESOME!

Firstly there's a lot to be said about how tight the design is: I'm learning to make games at the moment and this one has been on my list of "must examine this because it's brilliant" for a good six months. 

Here's some of my thoughts:

1. This is easily one of the most gorgeous looking roguelike games out there. The glowing graphics and animated effects (yes, even in ASCII) are bright, colourful and evocative of the machine-run sci-fi world the game so beautifully represents. The sound effects are solid yet unintrusive, and add a huge amount to the feeling of being drawn into the world around you. This is why we play games with ASCII or simplistic tilesets right? To let the imagination take hold too. The graphical ingenuity in this game never detracts from that imaginative immersion. You can seamlessly flick between the great tileset graphics and the ASCII mode, and this effect is used to great effect in transitions between levels, amongst others.

2. The story is introduced subtly and revealed through exploration. I gather you can play through the game and happily ignore it, although I've found that a combat mechanics focused game like this is only vastly improved with fluff. The fact the lore comes in pieces only adds to the atmosphere. There's a cool story there if you look for it. Just when you feel overwhelmed by the mammoth task ahead of you, you'll suddenly find an oasis in the desert... moments like these are wonderful when they come.

3. The combat mechanics are complex but so well hidden that you don't have to stare at mountains of data in order to perform well. This game will delight stat nerds and people who fear numbers in equal measure I think. There's a game of monsterous complexity under the hood, but the extent to which you interface with that is largely up to you. Everything is tool-tipped, which leads to the...

4. ...superb User Interface: roguelike developers the world over need to look at how good the UI is on Cogmind. It's almost perfect. Menus and game critical information is easily accessed (or, very importantly,  hidden from view) with a single key-press. The game can be played perfectly well with just the keyboard, with just the mouse, or a combination of both. The menus are animated to look like what a Unix operator tripping on acid in the 70's probably thought Unix would look like in the year 2000! 

5. Anybody with an appetite for monsterously large amounts of gear to blow up, assimilate and use are going to be in 7th heaven. There's a seemingly endless amount of different guns, legs, reactors, scanners, data hackers... you name it, there's probably about twenty of whatever you named in there. And yet the game doesn't seem to suffer any loss in design elegance for all this "stuff". It never feels bloaty and everything in the game (that I've come across so far) has a use in one of the many custom builds you'll find yourself exploring.

6: There are so many ways to play though. Stealthy airborn data analyser who spots threats way before they spot you then hacks their way past danger? Check. Massive firepower tanky bulk-lord who can literally roll over your foes, guns blazing? Check! Burrow your way through walls to avoid trouble? Check! I could go on...

7: Still reading? Go buy this game and play it!

Negative points? Hmm... as with a lot of roguelikes, it can be very difficult, but the learning curve is actually quite well balanced. Like all good games, when you do die, you know why, and it's always your fault. That being said, you can sometimes feel overwhelmed by the sheer amount of enemies that the game throws at you, even at the start. This might put of casual players, but you very quickly learn how to avoid trouble until you're ready to deal with it. 

It's worth stating that you do need to know what you're getting yourself in for with this game. It's tough, and it's big. It requires repeated efforts to learn, but that never feels like a chore.

This is a CLASSIC dungeon crawl roguelike game updated for the 21st Century. Kyzrati has nailed every aspect of this game and raised the bar for the innovation you can get into a genre that has a tendancy to stagnate through dogmatic adherence to outdated ideas: Cogmind is infused with a superb reinvention and execution of the all those classical roguelike features that kept people playing those games in the first place. Cogmind is futuristic in every sense, it's immersive,  technically brilliant, tactically engaging, endlessly replayable and great fun! Buy!

Edit: just to add, how many developers do you know who would think of something as helpful as making a page for potential buyers showing off how the game will look in a range of popular screen resolutions? Seriously man, Josh Ge is a dude, he's thought of everything. One wonders what Nethack would be like if he'd been the lead designer on it? (playable, probably) :)

Wow!  Cogmind isn't for everyone - read the full description, including the warnings and system requirements, and maybe watch some Let's Plays depending on your spoiler tolerance - but if it's for you it's [i]amazing[/i] and well worth the purchase price.

[h1]Do you want...[/h1]

[b]... to immerse yourself in the experience of [i]being[/i] an AI with the ability to build and rebuild its robot body?[/b]  Cogmind is deliberately crafted for immersion, from the audio feedback on every action and log message to the fully animated and highly customizable GUI.  In my experience, the interface polish doesn't get in my way; it unobtrusively wires the AI's low-level programming up to my intuitions for seamless use.  And it's very solid low-level programming too, automating calculations like "fastest path to this point while avoiding known traps" and "current chance of this enemy hitting me" while providing full and ready access to the absolute precision befitting a machine.  I quickly found myself comfortable inhabiting the little processing core that could, even when using parts that add on new senses entirely.  The atmosphere and immersion is [i]just that good[/i].

[b]... a heavily adjustable challenge in exploring a deep, living world?[/b]  Roguelikes are [i]hard[/i] by default, and Cogmind is no exception; indeed, the default difficulty is the hardest.  At its simplest, turn down the difficulty, attach the highest-rated parts (each part has an overall rating visible as soon as you find it), and shoot up some robots - or just watch them go about their work, which usually isn't about you.  If you want a challenge beyond the default, multiple endings, an extended endgame, and conducts galore are available.  You can also go spoiler-free without having to write things down yourself; in-game galleries are provided for both found parts and found [i]lore[/i] (the lore is entirely optional) and are available at any time.  The parts gallery is especially valuable for considering specialized build options - overall part rating is only a starting point, as there are several factors to balance and many possible synergies for the various strategies available.

[b]... an active community and extremely responsive developer?[/b]  When I was reading about Cogmind, I saw an old comment made by a single person suggesting that the arrow keys movement scheme could handle diagonal movement by using the modifiers Shift for "up and" and Ctrl for "down and" on an arrow direction.  That's in the game now - the sole developer put it in in response to that one comment.  Indeed, the developer is frequently on the game's forums, subreddit, and Discord server, all of which have systems for spoiler avoidance should you so desire it.  (There are also regular gameplay streams by players of varying experience levels, but it's much harder to avoid spoilers in those.)  Personally I mostly use the Discord, which has conversations several times a day and readily welcomes new players.

If these appeal to you and the warnings don't put you off, you will probably enjoy being a Cogmind.
